title: Electric field - direction of field between plates

content.description: Two conducting plates of area <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> are separated by a distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi></math>, as shown. The upper plate has a net charge of <math alttext="positive Q" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mpadded> <mo>+</mo> <mi>Q</mi> </mpadded> </math> and the lower plate has a net charge of <math alttext="negative Q" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math>. Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> is located a distance <math alttext="s" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>s</mi> </math> above the center of the lower plate and closer to the lower plate than the upper plate. Assume the plate dimensions are very large compared to <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi></math> and all gravitational forces are negligible.
content.question: Which of the following correctly indicates the direction of the electric field at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: The electric field is in the <math alttext="positive y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></mpadded></math>-direction because the charges are equal and opposite.

The electric field is in the <math alttext="positive y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></mpadded></math>-direction because electric fields point away from negative charge and toward positive charge.

The electric field is in the <math alttext="negative y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi></mpadded></math>-direction because Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> is farther from the positively charged plate.

The electric field is in the <math alttext="negative y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi></mpadded></math>-direction because electric fields point away from positive charge and toward negative charge.

content.answer: The electric field is in the <math alttext="negative y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi></mpadded></math>-direction because electric fields point away from positive charge and toward negative charge.
